status_message:
The author makes a number of excellent points about future work and present government subsidies and tax-benefit private programs.  But he misses the clear implication of such policies if not checked: employers will increasingly be rewarded for not paying a living wage, and it will be the responsibility of government (taxpayers) to pick up the difference.
The only way to prevent this is to insist on either:
A.  A living wage by all employers who provide full time work, or
B. A Basic Guaranteed income for everyone, regardless of other income.  From what the author adds up, it's clear a B.I.G. would be affordable if it replaced the slew of programs that currently represents such a huge part of federal, state and local budgets.
Moving towards a living-wage minimum wage and a B.I.G. would eliminate those marginal jobs which take time away from families while providing minimal social benefit, if any.  Is it really better to go to a fast food place with underpaid workers than to have a family dinner at home?  Is it better to shop at big box stores with underpaid clerks than to shop locally at stores that pay a living wage for only those things people really need?
A whole basket of good changes emerges with the right policy changes.

status_message:
I was happy to be the guest of Lou Puliafito on "A Decent Life" for the third time. We discussed the topics of my recent book: "America is Not Broke!" including:
1. Sovereign Money, aka Greenbacking
2. Land Value Taxation, aka Georgism
3. Public Banking
4. Not discussed but in the book - Ending Government Financial Asset Hoarding (GFAH)

We hope to meet again to continue to conversation, perhaps tying it into the recent economic surrender in Greece, and possible Sovereign Money/Land-Tax options.
